questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and ascites. Imaging reveals obstruction of hepatic venous outflow consistent with Budd-Chiari syndrome. Which of the following statements best explains the preservation of the caudate lobe in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The caudate lobe has a separate arterial supply that protects it from hepatic venous obstruction.

options.label: B
options.text: The caudate lobe drains directly into the inferior vena cava via emissary veins, bypassing the obstructed hepatic veins.

options.label: C
options.text: The caudate lobe is less affected by portal hypertension due to its anatomical position.

options.label: D
options.text: The caudate lobe undergoes necrosis less frequently than other liver segments in Budd-Chiari syndrome.

questions.correct_answer: B. The caudate lobe drains directly into the inferior vena cava via emissary veins, bypassing the obstructed hepatic veins.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure involving the stomach, the surgeon needs to ensure adequate blood supply. Which artery should the surgeon be most concerned about when addressing the lesser curvature of the stomach?

During a cholecystectomy, a surgeon encounters a variation in the biliary anatomy where the cystic duct is unusually short and close to the hepatic duct. Which of the following structures must the surgeon identify to avoid injury and ensure proper bile drainage?
Which of the following structures is not a component of the sphincter of Oddi?

A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a liver imaging study. The radiologist explains that dividing the liver into physiological lobes is important for understanding liver anatomy and function. Which of the following is primarily responsible for dividing the liver into physiological lobes?

Match the following Sectors of the liver with their respective segments. 1. Right Posterior Sector a) Segments IV 2. Right Anterior Sector b) Segments III 3. Left Medial Sector c) Segment VII 4. Left Lateral Sector d) Segments V
questions.explanation:
Fissure Type

Location

Structures it divides

Major Fissures

Main Portal Fissure

Liver parenchyma
  • Contains the Middle hepatic vein
  • Divides the liver into right and left hemilivers.

Left Portal Fissure

Liver parenchyma
  • Contains the left hepatic vein
  • Divides the left hemiliver into medial and lateral sectors

Right Portal Fissure

Liver parenchyma
  • Contains the right hepatic vein
  • Divides the right hemiliver into anterior and posterior sectors

Minor Fissures

Umbilical Fissure

Surface of the liver
  • Divides segments II and III from segment IV

Venous Fissure

Surface of the liver
  • Contains the ligamentum venosum
  • Separates the caudate lobe from segment II.

Fissure of Gans

Surface of the liver
  • Found on the undersurface of the right lobe
  • Surface landmark

Sector

Segments

Right Posterior Sector

Segments VI and VII

Right Anterior Sector

Segments V and VIII

Left Medial Sector

Segment IV (and part of I)

Left Lateral Sector

Segments II and III

questions.text: A patient is undergoing imaging for liver evaluation. The radiologist describes a segment located posterior to the right hepatic vein and in the superior part of the right posterior sector. Which segment of the liver is being described?
questions.explanation:
Segments of the liver

Segment VIII:

  • The superior part of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Drains into the right and middle hepatic veins.

Segment I (Caudate Lobe):

  • Posterior to segment IV, straddles the inferior vena cava.
  • Drainage: Multiple small veins drain directly into the inferior vena cava.
  • Bile Ducts: Related to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.

Segment II:

  • Posterolateral to the left portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Drains into the left hepatic vein; rarely directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment VII:

  • The superior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right hepatic vein.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the right hepatic vein; occasionally directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment III:

  • Between the umbilical and left portal fissures.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the left hepatic vein; alternative drainage via falciform ligament veins.

Segment VI:

  • Inferior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Usually into the right hepatic vein; may drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment V:

  • Inferior segment of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Typically into the right and middle hepatic veins; can drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment IV:

  • Between the umbilical fissure and main portal fissure, anterior to segment I.
  • Drainage: Usually into the middle hepatic vein; can also drain into the left hepatic vein.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man presents with symptoms of gastric dysmotility and increased acid secretion. Which structures are primarily involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the stomach?

options.label: A
options.text: Greater splanchnic nerves and coeliac plexus

questions.correct_answer: B. Vagus nerves and their branches
questions.explanation:
Sympathetic Innervation

Parasympathetic Innervation
  • Derived from T6 to T10 spinal segments via greater splanchnic nerves.
  • Fibers run along arteries via coeliac and hepatic plexuses.
  • Functions:
    • Vasomotor (regulates blood flow).
    • Motor to pyloric sphincter.
    • Inhibits the remaining gastric musculature.
    • Pathway for pain sensations from the stomach
  • Derived from vagus nerves.
  • Anterior vagal trunk:
    • Hepatic branch: Supplies liver, gallbladder, and pyloric antrum.
    • Coeliac branch: Follows left gastric artery to celiac plexus.
    • Gastric branch -Nerve of Latarjet: The largest branch, follows the lesser curvature to supply the anterior gastric surface down to the pylorus.
  • Posterior vagal trunk:
    • Smaller gastric branches: For posterior fundus, body, and pyloric antrum.
    • Larger coeliac branches: For coeliac plexus.
    • The nerve of Grassi: One or more branches of the posterior vagal trunk originate at the level of the gastroesophageal junction and supply the gastric fundus.
  • Functions:
    • Motor and secretomotor to stomach.
    • Stimulates gastric motility and secretion of pepsin and HCl.
    • Inhibits pyloric sphincter.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not part of the stomach bed?

A 60 y/o woman presents with abdominal pain localized to the upper right quadrant. Imaging reveals a mass adjacent to the uncinate process of the pancreas. Which part of the duodenum is most likely in direct relation to this mass?
questions.explanation:
First Part

Second Part

Third Part

Fourth part
  • Anteriorly: Quadrate lobe of liver, gallbladder.
  • Posteriorly: Portal vein, gastroduodenal artery, bile duct.
  • Superiorly: Epiploic foramen.
  • Inferiorly: Head and neck of the pancreas.
  • Anteriorly: Liver, transverse colon, small intestine.
  • Posteriorly: Right kidney, renal vessels, IVC, psoas major.
  • Medially: Head of the pancreas, bile duct.
  • Laterally: Right colic flexure.
  • Anteriorly: Superior mesenteric vessels, the root of the mesentery.
  • Posteriorly: IVC, abdominal aorta, right ureter, gonadal vessels.
  • Superiorly: Head of the pancreas with the uncinate process.
  • Inferiorly: Coils of jejunum.
  • Anteriorly: Transverse colon, transverse mesocolon, stomach.
  • Posteriorly: Left psoas major, left sympathetic chain, left renal artery.
  • Superiorly: Body of pancreas.
  • To the left: Left kidney, left ureter.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of the ileum compared to the jejunum?

options.label: D
options.text: Larger and more prominent circular folds

questions.explanation:
Feature

Jejunum

Ileum

Diameter

Larger (4 cm external, 3 cm internal)

Smaller (3 cm external, 2.5 cm internal)

Wall Thickness

Thicker, more vascular

Thinner, less vascular (Option A)

Circular Folds

Deeper, more numerous

Flatter, less numerous distally (Option D)

Mesentery

Shorter

Longer

Arteries

Larger, with 1-3 tiers of arcades

Smaller, with 2-6 tiers of arcades

Straight Arteries

Fewer, longer

More numerous, shorter (Option C)

Lymphoid Tissue

Fewer Peyer's patches

More Peyer’s patches, especially in terminal 25 cm (Option B)

Villi

Taller, more numerous

Shorter, fewer towards the distal end

questions.text: A 45 y/o male patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. A CT scan reveals multiple appendices epiploicae, particularly prominent in the sigmoid colon. Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the large intestine is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The caecum is typically 8-10 cm long and is a common site for appendices epiploicae.

options.label: B
options.text: The sigmoid colon, which is S-shaped, leads directly into the rectum.

options.label: C
options.text: The total length of the large intestine in adults ranges from 1 to 1.5 meters.

options.label: D
options.text: Appendices epiploicae are more common in the distal colon.

questions.correct_answer: A. The caecum is typically 8-10 cm long and is a common site for appendices epiploicae.
questions.explanation:
Component

Description

Caecum (Option A)

Blind pouch at the beginning of the large intestine and is approximately 6 cm long

Vermiform Appendix

Narrow tube, 6-10 cm long, attached to the caecum

Ascending Colon

Travels upward from the caecum (20-25cm long)

Right Colic Flexure

Bend between ascending and transverse colon

Transverse Colon

Crosses the abdomen horizontally

Left Colic Flexure

Bend between transverse and descending colon

Descending Colon

Travels downward from the left colic flexure (10-15 cm long)

Sigmoid Colon

S-shaped segment leading to the rectum (Option B ruled out)

Rectum

Final straight portion, ~15 cm above the anal canal

Feature

Details

Description

Small, fat-filled pouches of peritoneum on the colon's surface.

Location

Few or absent on caecum and ascending colon (Option A).

More common on the distal colon (Option D ruled out).

Numerous on the sigmoid colon; can enlarge with obesity.

Absent on rectum.

Type of Taeniae Coli

Position

Free Taenia

Located on the antimesenteric aspect, opposite the mesentery.

Omental Taenia

Positioned posterolaterally.

Mesocolic Taenia

Positioned posteromedially, between the free taenia and the mesentery.
